feed.title: Review: Saints Row: The Third
feed.subtitle: The game features loads of adult humor coupled with frantic, nonstop action.

category.term: 317~Saints Row~Saints Row: The Third~Sony PlayStation3~Rockstar Games Inc.
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
Platforms: X360, PC, PS3

The Deal: When THQ released its sandbox crime fest "Saints Row" back in 2006, it was instantly thought of as a poor man's "Grand Theft Auto" -- but that couldn't be further from the truth. Unlike the gritty ultraviolence found in its Rockstar-created counterpart, "Saints Row" placed gamers in a brighter environment filled with humor and over-the-top moments. The game's overall success led to a sequel in 2008, which earned several "Game of the Year" nods from websites and publications, thanks to its continued use of madcap comedy and constant breaks from reality. Now, after years of clawing itself out of the tremendous shadow of "Grand Theft Auto," THQ is ready to bring its third title to the "Saints Row" family and show the world how to do open-world gaming with style.

Now that they own the streets of Stilwater, the Third Street Saints have become quite the celebrities. Sadly, The Syndicate, an ultrapowerful, worldwide criminal organization, wants a piece of the action, but the headstrong Saints won't budge. With a goal of taking down The Syndicate, the Saints travel to Steelport, a once-proud city that has been filled to overflowing with crime, and wage a war, one block at a time. Keeping with the "Saints Row" love of humor, you'll also do battle with zombies, Mexican wrestlers and military forces along the way.

"Saints Row: The Third" is a third-person action game that has you playing a member of the Third Street Saints as you shoot at, blow up and run over everything and everyone in your way. That is where the similarities to "Grand Theft Auto" end. What comes next is an endless supply of wacky misadventures that include human cannonball cars, tank sky diving and jet surfing, all while wearing insane costumes. While some of these events may seem too zany for die-hard action fans, don't worry. The game is still filled with missions that will have you taking down criminal operations, driving at high speeds and assassinating important Syndicate members.

With loads of adult humor coupled with frantic, nonstop action, it's plain to see that anyone who enjoys shooters and has the ability to purchase M-rated games will fall in love with "Saints Row: The Third." It's for these simple facts that THQ has not only set itself apart from "GTA" but forced Rockstar Games to take note and do its best to keep up.
